meta.title: Dementia - Lewy Body Dementia & Vascular Dementia (Part 2)

questions.text: Patients with the following MRI are also seen in some normal individuals. which of the following is a correct answer:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dementia of vascular etiology FLAIR: MRI (Axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) through the lateral ventricle reveals multiple areas of confluent diffuse hyperintensity in the periventricular white matter as well as the corona radiata and striatum Although seen in some individuals with normal cognition , this appearance is more pronounced in patients with dementia of a vascular etiology.

Highyeild:

Vascular dementia- 2nd most common cause of dementia in elderly. Sudden onset (hallmark) Step ladder pattern of decline Pronounced gait abnormality -Repeated falls UMN findings- Spasticity, Increased DTR / Increased plantar reflexes Apathy Emotional incontinence -Explosive crying, laughter Cognitive slowing.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Alzheimer’s disease -There will be reduction in medial temporal lobe volume in the patient with Alzheimer’s disease Option: C Hydrocephalus -There will be dilation of ventricle. Option: D Pneumocephalus -Multiple air pockets should be seen in CT.

questions.text: A 78-year-old Mrs. Mehta presents to a clinic for evaluation of progressive memory loss. Six months ago she had a small right parietal stroke. Immediately after the stroke, she had short-term memory deficits, which have persisted. Then, 3 months ago she developed a new slowing of her cognitive processing. Two weeks ago, her family noticed that she no longer knew how to use her kitchen appliances. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed subcortical white matter disease and no evidence of prior hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vascular dementia Old patient, with a stepladder pattern of cognitive decline,not necessarily related to specific ischemic insults (history of stroke), but related to the cumulative burden of ischemic disease, suggests Vascular dementia. Neuroimaging in patients with Vascular Dementia classically demonstrates a cortical and/or subcortical infarction with or without deep white matter changes from chronic ischemia which is seen on MRI Brain of this patient.

Highyeild:

Vascular dementia- 2nd most common cause of dementia in elderly. Sudden onset (hallmark) Step ladder pattern of decline Pronounced gait abnormality -Repeated falls UMN findings- Spasticity, Increased DTR / Increased plantar reflexes Apathy Emotional incontinence -Explosive crying, laughter Cognitive slowing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Alzheimer disease- leads to progressive , not stepwise , deficits in memory , language , visuospatial defects, and executive function. Option:B. Frontotemporal dementia -has varied presentations, but most often presents with behavioral disturbances and poor executive function . Option:D. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy- can cause dementia , but most often presents with a lobar intracerebral hemorrhage and evidence of multifocal hemorrhages.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient is brought to OPD. The problems started three months ago when the patient stopped cooking and cleaning the house. Her gait has become unsteady, and she has had two near falls over the last 2 months. She is mildly forgetful. She has a history of hypertension, stable coronary artery disease, and diabetes mellitus. There is mild muscle weakness on the left side.There is no muscle rigidity. She is unsteady in the Romberg position with her eyes closed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cognitive impairment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vascular dementia Old age , hypertension , coronary artery disease , diabetes and history of stroke . (chronic ischemic condition) with abrupt, stepwise decline in executive function , mild forgetfulness, and focal neurologic deficits (left hemiparesis, pronator drift, Romberg sign) are consistent with likely ischemic stroke and subsequent vascular dementia (Vascular Dementia).

Highyeild:

Vascular dementia- 2nd most common cause of dementia in elderly. Sudden onset (hallmark) Step ladder pattern of decline Pronounced gait abnormality -Repeated falls UMN findings- Spasticity, Increased DTR / Increased plantar reflexes Apathy Emotional incontinence -Explosive crying, laughter Cognitive slowing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Normal aging will have gradual decline in mental processing capacity and can result in occasional forgetfulness, but should not interfere with daily living as seen in this patient. Option: B. Lewy body dementia has no visual hallucinations and parkinsonism features (Rigidity absent) in this patient.. Option: C. Frontotemporal dementia no personality changes or disinhibition and compulsive behavior in this patient.

questions.text: Mrs. Shetty, 66, is brought to OPD by her son due to increasing confusion, loss of mobility.The patient recently exclaimed that"a lion was sleeping in the backyard". She has memory loss. She appears alert but disoriented and quite agitated .On Physical examination she has increased muscle tone, normal reflexes,and coarse resting tremors in the extremities. When the patient becomes combative, she is given a small dose of risperidone, which only aggravates her stiffness.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dementia with Lewy bodies As the patient has fluctuating cognition and bizarre, visual hallucinations, Parkinsonism features (rigidity+tremor), increased sensitivity to antipsychotics,

Highyeild:

Lewy body dementia- Early visual hallucination REM sleep abnormality Delirium/ fluctuating -mental status Capgras syndrome -false belief that an identical duplicate has replaced someone significant to the patient. Increased sensitivity to medicines like Antipsychotics → Increase risk of Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Syncopal episodes Autonomic dysfunction Memory is not affected. Parkinsonism→ Dementia Gap>2yr: Parkinson's associated dementia Gap<1yr: Lewy body dementia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Alzheimer disease is a progressive dementia without visual hallucination, muscle rigidity. Option: C. Frontotemporal dementia no personality changes or disinhibition and compulsive behavior in this patient.. Option: D. Vascular dementia The decline in function typically proceeds stepwise , with stability or partial improvement in the interim.It is typically associated with focal neurologic findings with the specific symptoms determined by location of the infarcts.

questions.text: The cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is a genetic disorder linked to a mutation in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NOTCH3 gene on chromosome 19 The cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy ( CADASIL ) is a genetic disorder linked to a mutation in NOTCH3. gene on chromosome 19 Option A,B, and D are incorrect.

Highyeild:

CADASIL (cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcorical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy)- an inherited disorder (autosomal dominant) presents as small-vessel strokes or progressive dementia. extensive symmetric white matter changes, often including the anterior temporal lobes, visualized by MRI . Approximately 40% of patients have migraines with aura , which often manifest as transient motor or sensory deficits . Onset is usually in the fourth or fifth decade of life. This autosomal dominant condition is caused by one of several mutations in Notch-3 gene on chromosome 19 , a member of a highly conserved gene family characterized by epidermal growth factor repeats in its extracellular domain.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the OPD by her son. He is concerned because his mother had an unprovoked fall a year ago and has since relied on him to coordinate her activities and make decisions about everyday matters. The patient's symptoms seemed to improve until she sustained another significant fall about 6 months ago .She has also become mildly forgetful, experiences occasional mood swings, and now seems sad most of the time. Neurologic examination shows weakness and sensory deficits on the right side. MMSE is significant for low volume of speech and flat affect. Neuroimaging would most likely show which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cortical and/or subcortical infarctions This patient's presentation is consistent with likely undiagnosed strokes and subsequent vascular dementia . Old patient having a sudden change in functional status starting a year ago after an unprovoked fall (e.g., planning activities, making decisions). She also shows a stepwise decline in functioning, entailing some improvement in symptoms but followed by another fall (possibly a repeat stroke) (weakness and sensory deficit on examination ) and subsequent problems with mood swings (Emotional incontinence), flat affect (Apathy) This patient's early mild forgetfulness is also typical of Vascular dementia and can help differentiate it from the more profound memory problems seen in Alzheimer disease . Neuroimaging in patients with Vascular Dementia classically demonstrates a cortical and/or subcortical infarction with or without deep white matter changes from chronic ischemia.

Highyeild:

Vascular dementia- 2nd most common cause of dementia in elderly. Sudden onset (hallmark) Step ladder pattern of decline Pronounced gait abnormality -Repeated falls UMN findings- Spasticity, Increased DTR / Increased plantar reflexes Apathy Emotional incontinence -Explosive crying, laughter Cognitive slowing.

But, it is not typically associated with any neuroimaging abnormalities. Option: B . Ventriculomegaly is seen in normal-pressure hydrocephalus , which initially presents with ataxia followed by dementia and urinary incontinence. Option: C.
